method.text: Heat <sup>2</sup>/<sub>3</sub> of the butter in a large pan. Add the onions. Fry for 3-5 min until softened.
Toss the steak in the seasoned flour until well coated. Add the steak and kidney to the pan. Fry for 8-10 min, stirring frequently until well browned. Remove meat from pan. Keep warm with the onions.
Meanwhile, add the red wine, stock and mushrooms to the pan. Cover and simmer for 1 hour until meat is tender.
Sift the flour, baking powder and seasoning into a bowl. Stir in the thyme and suet and enough cold water to mix to a soft but not sticky dough.
Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured work surface. Roll out to a 25 cm (10in) round. Cut out a quarter and reserve for the lid.
Arrange the dough in a lightly buttered 1.15 litre (2pt) ovenproof pudding basin. Join the edges together so the base is evenly lined and any extra dough hangs over the rim of the basin.

Strain the liquid for the meat and reduce if necessary. Spoon the meat and mushroom mixture into the lined basin. Spoon over the juices, leaving a small gap between the top of the pudding and the rim of the basin.

Roll out the remaining pastry to form a lid. Moisten the edges of both lid and basin with a little water. Arrange the pastry lid on top of the filling. Flip over the pastry hanging over the edge and press down gently to seal well.

Cover the pudding with a lightly buttered piece of pleated foil, to allow for expansion. Tie securely around the rim with string. Using a length of foil, make a handle to wrap around the pudding to make it easier when lifting out.

Stand the basin on a trivet in a large saucepan. Pour in enough boiling water to come half way up the sides of the basin. Cover and steam for 2 <sup>1</sup>/<sub>1</sub> days, topping up the water when necessary. Do not turn out to serve but remove the foil and tie a clean napkin around the basin before serving.
